questions.text: The structure marked "?" in the image is composed of _____ cartilage.
questions.solution:
The structure marked "?" in the image is the thyroid cartilage, and it is composed of hyaline cartilage.

Thyroid cartilage is identified by the presence of superior and inferior horns, and its relation with the epiglottis and larynx. The given image shows a cut-open view of the larynx from the back, and here, the thyroid cartilage encases the larynx anteriorly. The stalk of the epiglottis is also seen attached to the inner surface of the thyroid cartilage.

Hyaline cartilage is made up of chondrocytes and matrix:

  • The chondrocytes in the deeper matrix are rounded in shape and may appear in groups of eight that originate from the mitotic divisions of a single chondroblast. These groups of cells are called isogenous cell aggregates or cell nests.
  • The important components of the matrix are type II collagen, aggrecan (proteoglycan), and chondronectin (glycoprotein).
  • The matrix that immediately surrounds the chondrocytes is basophilic and is known as the territorial matrix, whereas the matrix that is more distant from the cells appears pale and is known as the interterritorial matrix.

Hyaline cartilage is found at various sites:

  • Larger respiratory passages (nose, larynx, trachea, and bronchi)
  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Cricoid cartilage
  • Base of the arytenoid cartilage
  • Ventral end of ribs, where they articulate with the sternum
  • Epiphyseal plate of long bones
  • Articular cartilage of synovial joints 
  • Temporary skeleton in embryo

On microscopy, hyaline cartilage can be identified by the following characteristics:

  • Presence of chondrocytes within lacunae.
  • Group of two or more chondrocytes, which are known as isogenous cell aggregates or cell nests
  • Basophilic territorial matrix and pale interterritorial matrix
  • Presence of perichondrium with outer fibrous and the inner cellular layer

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

Type of Cartilage Hyaline Cartilage Elastic Cartilage Fibrocartilage
Colour Bluish opalescent Yellow White
Collagen type Type 2 Type 2 Type 1 (mainly) and type 2
Perichondrium Present (except at epiphyses & articular cartilage) Present Absent
Calcification Occurs with old age No calcification Occurs only with bone repair
Cells Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Fibroblasts & chondrocytes
Fibres Thin collagen Elastic fibres Thick collagen
Examples

Arytenoids except for apices

Cricoid cartilage

Thyroid cartilage

Trachea and bronchi

Articular cartilage at ends of bones

Epiphyseal plate

questions.text: The type of laryngoscope blade shown in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Miller laryngoscopic blade. 

A laryngoscope is an instrument used for examination of the larynx and facilitation of tracheal intubation. It has three components: the handle, the blade, and the light source. The Macintosh and Miller blades are the most popularly used blades.

Miller's blade is a straight blade. Its curve begins 2 inches from the tip. It is inserted using the para-glossal technique. This technique avoids contact with the maxillary incisors and provides maximal tongue control.

It is used in:

  • Neonates, infants, and young children
  • Adults with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.

Macintosh blade is a sharply curved blade with a large flange. It is inserted in the right side of the mouth, and the flange is used to sweep the tongue to the left. The blade is advanced and positioned in the vallecula. Advantages of a curved blade include:

  • Greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought with severe pain in his right thigh which has worsened over the last few months. He also has frequent nose bleeds and gets fatigued easily while playing. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leukocyte assay with low levels of beta-glucosidase activity. What is the inheritance pattern of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of bone pain, epistaxis, hepatosplenomegaly, and low levels of β-glucosidase suggests a diagnosis of Gaucher's disease that is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

Gaucher's disease is an inborn error of metabolism due to the deficiency of the enzyme acid β-glucosidase. This leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide in the cells of the reticuloendothelial system.

The clinical features result from the accumulation of lipid-laden macrophages in the spleen, liver, bone marrow, bone, and other tissues. It is characterized by hematologic abnormalities, organomegaly, and skeletal involvement like bone pain and pathological fractures. There are 3 clinical subtypes :

Type 1 - presents from early childhood to late adulthood. These patients present with:

  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Bone pain
  • Pathological fractures
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Chronic fatigue
  • Erlenmeyer flask deformity of distal femur

Type 2 - acute neuronopathic form. These patients have a rapid neurodegenerative course and present with increased tone, strabismus, and organomegaly. These patients die within 1 year of life.

Type 3 - juvenile or subacute neuronopathic form. It presents in childhood and there is death by 10-15 years of age.

Gaucher cells are the pathological hallmark of the disease. They are seen in the reticuloendothelial system, especially in the bone marrow. It has a wrinkled paper appearance due to the presence of intracytoplasmic inclusions. The cytoplasm of the Gaucher cell is strongly PAS-positive.

Gaucher's disease is treated with enzyme replacement therapy.

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

S. No.

Hexosaminidase A

2

Hexosaminidase A and B

Globoside & Ganglioside

Similar to Tay–Sachs disease but also has hepatosplenomegaly and skeletal dysplasias

3

α-Galactosidase

Skin rash, kidney failure (full symptoms only in males; X-linked recessive)

4

Arylsulfatase A

3-Sulfogalactosyl-ceramide

5

questions.text: Which of the following is the dose of vitamin A prophylaxis given to children between the ages of 1-5 years under the vitamin A distribution scheme in India?
questions.solution:
Under the vitamin-A distribution scheme in India, 200000 IU of vitamin A are given orally at 6-monthly intervals between the ages 1-5 years.

Vitamin A deficiency is a major public health problem among the lower-income population in India. Thus, India has a national program for the prevention of nutritional blindness. The beneficiaries include all pre-school children between 1-5 years of age.

The program focuses on the following things:

  1. Promoting intake of vitamin A-rich foods among preschool children, pregnant, and lactating mothers. The program also promotes appropriate breastfeeding.
  2. Supplementation of vitamin A in preschool children. The first dose of 100000 IU is given at 9 months of age with MMR vaccine. Subsequent doses of 200000 IU are given every 6 months till the age of 5 years.
  3. Prompt treatment of xerophthalmia at health facilities. Locally trained primary health workers are trained to treat a wide range of eye conditions like acute conjunctivitis, ophthalmia neonatorum, trachoma, and superficial foreign bodies.
  4. Supplementation of vitamin A (one dose) in children suffering from measles or severe malnutrition

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 4–6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-12 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinyl palmitate.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of postmortem hanging?
questions.solution:
The absence of a salivary dribble mark is a feature of postmortem hanging. The presence of a salivary dribble is a feature of antemortem hanging.

A salivary dribble mark is the surest sign of an antemortem hanging and is due to the consequence of pressure and friction on the submandibular salivary glands due to the ligature. This results in dribbling of the saliva from the angle of the mouth (angle opposite to the knot). 

The other options are all signs of antemortem hanging.

Option 1 - Oblique ligature mark is seen in antemortem hanging. This is in contrast to the circular ligature mark seen in postmortem hanging. 

Option 3 - Le facie sympathique is the term used to describe the phenomenon when the eye on the same side as the ligature mark remains open with a dilated pupil. This is caused by pressure on the cervical sympathetic chain of that side. It is an indicator of antemortem hanging. 

Option 4 - Tear of carotid artery intima, known as the Amussat's sign, is seen with antemortem hanging. These are transverse tears and are most clearly seen in obese victims and posteriorly placed knots. While the absence of this sign doesn't exclude antemortem hanging, it is never seen in postmortem hanging.

Related Pearl: Difference between Ante mortem and Post-mortem Hanging

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden painless loss of vision in his right eye. On fundus examination, the following finding was seen. Which among the following conditions is likely?
questions.solution:
The image shows a splashed sauce appearance which is characteristic of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). 

CRVO refers to sudden or acute occlusion of the central retinal vein. It presents with a sudden loss of vision. On examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect is present.

Funduscopy shows engorged and tortuous retinal veins, massive retinal hemorrhages with splashed tomato appearance, and cotton wool spots. The disc is edematous and hyperemic. Changes that occur later include neovascularization at the disc or periphery with pigmentary changes at the macula.

Complications:

  • Rubeosis iridis or neovascularization of the iris
  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) or 100 day glaucoma
  • Vitreous hemorrhage

100-day glaucoma is a type of neovascular glaucoma (NVG) and is so-called because it typically develops 3 months after the episode of CRVO.

Other options:

Option A- The funduscopy findings in central retinal artery occlusion include pale retina, thread-like arteries, a cherry-red spot in the macula, and cattle trucking (segmentation of blood in the retinal veins). It is shown below.

Option C: The funduscopy in retinal detachment shows detachment of fovea and macula, as shown below.

Option D: Fundoscopy changes in retinitis pigmentosa include perivascular retinal hyperpigmentation, narrow retinal arterioles, atrophy of retinal pigment epithelium, and disc pallor. It is shown below.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with complaints of bleeding from the nose after a fistfight. On evaluation, it was found to be a vertical fracture of the nasal septum. What is the name of the fracture suffered by this patient?
questions.solution:
Since it is a vertical fracture of the nasal septum, it is called a Chevallet fracture.

Injuries to the nasal septum can result from trauma to the nose from the front, side, or below. The septum may get buckled on itself, fracture vertically, horizontally, or get crushed.

A Chevallet fracture usually results from a blow to the nose from below. This fracture line runs vertically. It extends from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.

A Jarjaway fracture results from a blow to the nose from the front. The fracture line runs horizontally backward. It begins just above the anterior nasal spine and extends just above the junction of septal cartilage with the vomer. 

Patients with septal injuries with mucosal tears present with profuse epistaxis. Those with an intact mucosa may have a septal hematoma, which should be drained. 

Dislocated or fractured fragments of the septum should be repositioned and supported. This is done with mucoperichondrial flaps, mattress sutures, and nasal packing.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus has been prescribed pioglitazone. What will you tell her when she asks about the most common adverse effect of thiazolidinediones?
questions.solution:
The most common adverse effects of the thiazolidinediones are weight gain and edema.

Thiazolidinediones are a selective agonist of nuclear peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR-γ). They modulate the expression of genes involved in lipid and glucose metabolism, insulin signal transduction, and adipocyte differentiation. These effects increase the sensitivity of the tissues to insulin.

Pioglitazone and rosiglitazone are used to treat patients with type 2 diabetes. They are known to cause fluid retention and edema and therefore avoided in patients who have heart failure. 

Pioglitazone is metabolized in the liver and constant liver function monitoring is required as it is hepatotoxic. It is thus contraindicated in liver disease.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting insulin secretion

questions.text: The marked phase in the cardiac muscle action potential mainly occurs due to ______.
questions.solution:
The marked phase in the cardiac action potential is phase 3. It occurs due to the efflux of potassium ions.

Phases of the cardiac muscle action potential.

  • Phase 0 (depolarization): Opening of fast sodium channels. When the cardiac cell is stimulated, the fast sodium channels (voltage-gated sodium channels) open and cause sodium influx. This depolarizes the cell and the membrane potential becomes positive. It reaches about +20 mV. 
  • Phase 1 (initial repolarization): When the membrane potential reaches +20mV, the fast sodium channels close and the potassium channels open. The potassium ions leave the cell leading to a brief repolarisation. 
  • Phase 2 (plateau): Fast potassium channels close and calcium channels open. The voltage-gated Ca2+ channels start opening slowly in phases 0 and 1. The influx of calcium through these channels is balanced by the decrease in the efflux of potassium via the potassium channels. This produces the plateau. 
  • Phase 3 (rapid repolarization): Slow potassium channels open and calcium channels close. The potassium ions leave the cell through slow potassium channels and the calcium channels close, stopping the influx of calcium ions. This ends the plateau and brings the membrane potential to the resting level. 
  • Phase 4 (resting membrane potential):  around −80 to −90 millivolts.

The illustration given below shows action potential of cardiac muscle.

Differences in the cardiac and the skeletal muscles - The action potentials of the skeletal muscle are almost entirely caused by the sudden opening of large numbers of fast sodium channels. In cardiac muscle, it is mainly caused by fast sodium channels and L-type calcium channels (slow calcium channels).

Related Pearl: Anti-arrhythmic drugs

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with right wrist pain. She says that the pain aggravates while working and improves with rest. On examination, there is local tenderness in the area of the dorsal radial styloid. There is no limitation of motion, but the ulnar deviation is very painful. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of De Quervain's disease.

De Quervain's disease is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It involves noninflammatory thickening of both the tendons and the tunnel or sheath through which they pass. This condition is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

Key diagnostic factors:

  • History of joint overuse at home or at work.
  • Pain and tenderness at the tip of radial styloid.
  • Positive Finkelstein test

Finkelstein's test - The examiner grasps the thumb of the patient and abducts the hand towards the ulnar side. This causes severe pain over the tip of the styloid process. It is positive in the following conditions:

  • De Quervain's disease (tenosynovitis)
  • Arthritis in the intercarpal and radiocarpal joints
  • Superficial radial nerve entrapment 
  • Intersection syndrome i.e. tenosynovitis occurs due to friction between the obliquely placed extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis tendons and the longitudinally placed extensor tendons.

Treatment of De Quervain's disease includes conservative management in the majority of the patients with steroid injection. Only a few require surgical release of the 1st dorsal compartment (housing the APL and EPB tendons).

Other options:

The site of pain and tenderness can be diagnostic

Condition Site of pain
Kienböck’s disease Over the lunate
Scaphoid fracture Anatomical snuffbox
Carpometacarpal osteoarthritis The base of the first metacarpal


Note: Kienböck’s disease is the traumatic softening of the lunate bone. This condition is characterized by ischemic necrosis which may be due to chronic stress or injury.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents to the OPD with amenorrhea for the last 8 months. She complains of a loss of libido and problems with intercourse with her partner. There is a previous history of chronic radiation exposure. Investigations are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

FSH: 55 IU/L 
Prolactin: 20 ng/mL 
Pregnancy test: Negative
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a history of amenorrhea and loss of libido with chronic radiation exposure and elevated FSH levels (> 40 IU/L) in a 35-year-old female point toward the diagnosis of premature ovarian failure.

Premature ovarian failure is defined as ovarian failure occurring before the age of 40 years. Clinically, it presents as secondary amenorrhoea for at least 3 months with raised FSH, raised FSH/LH ratio, and low estrogen.

Causes of POF

  • Migration of germ cells from the yolk sac.
  • Germ cell apoptosis.
    • Chromosomal abnormalities
    • Autoimmune diseases - hypothyroidism, Addison's disease, etc
    • Genital TB
    • Smoking
    • Radiation and chemotherapy
    • Hysterectomy
    • Prolonged GnRH therapy
    • Induction of multiple ovulation.

Clinical features include amenorrhea, hot flashes, sweating, diminished libido, vaginal dryness, and urinary symptoms.

Management:

  • Treatment of cause
  • If not interested in pregnancy:
    • Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) - Libido improves with estrogen therapy
  • If interested in pregnancy:
    • Ovulation induction (if an ovarian reserve is present) or donor eggs for in vitro fertilization.

Other options:

Option B: Patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome would have presented with primary amenorrhea. Karyotyping would reveal a 46XY karyotype. LH is raised, but FSH is normal. 

Option C: A prolactinoma would present with elevated prolactin levels.

Option D: In polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), there are features like menstrual abnormalities, obesity, and hyperandrogenism. LH level is raised, FSH level remains normal, but FSH/LH ratio falls. Estrogen levels increase.

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2 P1 lady at her 20th week of gestation presents to the clinic. Her anomaly scan is suggestive of bilateral renal agenesis. On examination, her fundal height is 15 cm. Which among the following parameters is likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Bilateral renal agenesis leads to decreased production of amniotic fluid or oligohydramnios, and the single deepest vertical pocket will be less than 2 cm. (option D).

Oligohydramnios refers to an abnormally decreased amount of amnionic fluid. A diagnosis of oligohydramnios is made when amniotic fluid index (AFI) is less than 5 cm or a single deepest vertical pocket (DVP) of amniotic fluid is less than 2 cm.

Causes of oligohydraminios:

  • Placental abnormalities
  • Maternal complications leading to uteroplacental insufficiency: Pre-eclampsia, vascular disease
  • Renal anomalies:
    • Bilateral renal agenesis
    • Bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • Unilateral renal agenesis with contralateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • Infantile form of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney dis­ease
    • Fetal bladder outlet obstruction - posterior urethral valves, urethral atresia, or stenosis
  • Complex fetal anomalies: persistent cloaca and sireno­melia 
  • Drugs: ACE inhibitors, ARBs, NSAIDs when taken in the 2nd or 3rd trimester

Other options:

Options A and B imply polyhydramnios since the AFI is greater than 24 cm, and the single deepest vertical pocket (DVP) is greater than 8 cm.

Option C: AFI = 10 cm indicates normal AFI (5–25 cm)

Related Pearl: Causes of oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios

Causes

Oligohydramnios

Polyhydramnios

Maternal
  • Undiagnosed rupture of membrane (most common)
  • Spontaneous rupture of membranes
  • Post-dated pregnancy
  • Preeclampsia
  • NSAIDs
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Overt diabetes
  • Gestational diabetes
  • Cardiac disease
  • Renal disease
  • Liver failure

Fetal
  • Fetal anomalies
  • Renal agenesis
  • Urethral defects
    • Posterior valve
    • Obstructive uropathy

 
  • Multiple gestation
  • Neural tube defects
  • Abdominal wall defects
  • Cleft palate
  • Neck masses
  • Esophageal atresia
  • Aneuploidy
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • TTTS

Placental

Failure of secretion:- e.g. Amnion nodosum

Chorangioma of placenta

questions.text: A middle-aged lady was referred to a dermatology clinic for a lesion on her left cheek as shown in the image below. On diascopy, apple jelly nodules were seen. Skin biopsy showed tubercles with absent central caseation surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes in the superficial dermis.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows numerous reddish-brown papules with an elevated scaly surface and scarring. These lesions, together with the features of apple jelly nodules on diascopy and tubercles with absent central caseation, point towards a diagnosis of lupus vulgaris.

Lupus vulgaris is a chronic, progressive, paucibacillary form of cutaneous tuberculosis which occurs in previously sensitized individuals. The characteristic lesion is a plaque, consisting of soft, reddish-brown papules. It grows by slow peripheral extension, becoming discoid in shape with areas of atrophy. The lesions are acquired either by hematogenous spread or by direct inoculation. 

There are five clinical variants of lupus vulgaris:

  • Plaque form
  • Ulcerative and mutilating forms
  • Vegetating form
  • Tumor-like forms
  • Papular and nodular form

On diascopy, characteristic 'apple jelly nodules' are seen. Histology shows tubercles with scanty or absent central caseation, surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells, present in the superficial dermis. Usually, tubercle bacilli are scanty or absent. Treatment is by standard multidrug antituberculosis therapy.

Complications include scarring, contractures, and tissue destruction. Malignant changes (most commonly, squamous cell carcinomas) are known to arise in longstanding lupus vulgaris.

Other options:

Option A: Acne vulgaris- Lesions are due to inflammation of the pilosebaceous unit. It can present with open and closed comedones and/or papules, pustules, and nodules.

Option C: Tuberculoid leprosy- Typical lesions are erythematous, copper-colored, or purple plaques, with raised edges sloping towards a hypopigmented center.

Option D: Discoid lupus erythematosus: It is an inflammatory disorder of the skin. The lesions are characterized by well‐defined red, scaly patches of variable size.

The image below shows how diascopy is done:

questions.text: Parents of a child with febrile seizures are concerned about its relapse, complications, and treatment. All of the following are true regarding the risks and management of this case, except:

choices.text: Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of a recurrent febrile seizure
Nitrazepam, clobazam, and clonazepam, help to reduce the risks of recurrence of febrile seizures
Antiepileptic therapy can decrease the risk of future epilepsy
Iron deficiency is associated with an increased risk of febrile seizures

questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true, except for option C. Future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.

Febrile seizures are seizures that:

  • Occur between the age of 6 months and 5 years
  • Occur at a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  • Are not due to any CNS infection or any metabolic imbalance
  • Occur without a history of prior afebrile seizures
  • Occur with no post-ictal neurological deficit.

Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizures.

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Occurs within 24 hours of the onset of fever Can occur at any time during a fever
Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent
Chances of going into epilepsy 1% Chances of going into epilepsy 6%

Investigations:

  • Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months age (to exclude meningitis).
  • EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures.

Treatment:

Antipyretics and proper hydration. Midazolam or diazepam (rectal) can be used if seizures present.

Prophylaxis:

  • Intermittent prophylaxis: If the febrile seizures are 3 or more in 6 months, or 4 or more seizures in 1 year, oral clobazam (1mg/kg/day) for 3 days during the fever episode.
  • Continuous prophylaxis: If intermittent prophylaxis fails and in recurrent atypical febrile seizures, sodium valproate and phenobarbitone can be used.

Note:

  • Antipyretics can decrease the discomfort of the child but do not reduce the risk of having a recurrent febrile seizure.
  • Intermittent oral nitrazepam, clobazam, and clonazepam have also been used. Such therapies help reduce, but do not eliminate, the risks of recurrence of febrile seizures.
  • Future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.
  • Iron deficiency is associated with an increased risk of febrile seizures, and thus screening and treating it would be appropriate.

Risk Factors for Recurrence of Febrile Seizures:

Major:

  • Age <1 yr
  • Duration of fever <24 hr
  • Fever 38-39°C (100.4-102.2°F)

Minor:

  • Daycare
  • Male gender
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Lower serum sodium at time of presentation

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, who was a welder for the past 10 years presents with a dry cough, easy fatiguability, weight loss, and dyspnea progressing over the past 1 year. On examination, fine end-inspiratory crackles were heard over the bilateral infra-axillary regions. His HRCT finding is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The HRCT provided shows a characteristic crazy-paving pattern which is classical of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. 

Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is a lung disease involving the accumulation of surfactant within the alveoli as a result of decreased clearance. It may be congenital, secondary, or autoimmune.

Etiology:

  • Congenital
  • Secondary: due to lung infections, hematologic malignancies, and inhalation of mineral dust such as silica, titanium oxide, aluminum, indium-tin-oxide, and insecticides.
  • Autoimmune: autoantibodies against GM-CSF

Patients may have features like a persistent dry cough (or with scant sputum production), progressive dyspnea, fatigue, weight loss, intermittent low-grade fever and/or night sweats, and pleuritic chest pain. Rarely, they may have cyanosis and hemoptysis. The physical examination will show fine end-inspiratory crackles. Clubbing and cyanosis may be present in a few cases.

Diagnosis is with bronchoscopic lavage and/or biopsy, along with imaging findings. Chest X-ray shows nonspecific findings with bilateral lung opacification. A batwing appearance may be seen.

The CT shows a characteristic ‘crazy-paving’ pattern. It refers to geographical areas of ground-glass opacification with thickened inter-and intralobular septa.

Treatment includes whole lung lavage and treatment of the underlying cause. GM-CSF replacement is considered if an underlying autoimmune etiology is suspected.

Other causes causing similar crazy-paving appearance:

  • Lipoid pneumonia
  • Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Nonspecific interstitial pneumonia
  • Silicosis,
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text:
You assist in performing a Whipple procedure in a patient with carcinoma of the pancreas. All of the following structures will be resected in this surgery, except:
  1. Gallbladder
  2. Common bile duct
  3. Spleen
  4. Proximal jejunum
  5. Tail of the pancreas
questions.solution:
Whipple procedure does not involve the removal of the spleen and tail of the pancreas.

The Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas. It is done only in cases when:

  • The entire duodenum has to be removed e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
  • Tumor encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach
  • A clear resection margin is not achieved by pylorus preserving pancreatoduodectomy

The following structures are removed during Whipple’s procedure:

  • Distal stomach
  • Duodenum
  • Proximal jejunum
  • Head of the pancreas
  • Gallbladder
  • Common bile duct (CBD)
  • Regional lymphatics

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of non-pulsatile headache of tightening quality on both sides of his forehead. He describes it as wearing a tight cap. He has no nausea, photophobia, or phonophobia.  All of the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this condition except
questions.solution:
A bilateral, non-pulsatile headache of tightening quality without any nausea or photophobia suggests a diagnosis of tension-type headache (TTH). Triptans are not useful in the treatment of this condition. They are useful when the patient has a migraine headache.

  Tension-type headache Migraine  Cluster headache

Treatment

Analgesics

NSAIDs

Acetaminophen

NSAIDs

Triptans

Dihydroergotamine

100% oxygen

Sumatriptan

 
Prophylaxis Amitriptyline  
  • Lifestyle changes(eg, sleep,exercise, diet)
  • β-blockers
  • Calcium channel blockers
  • Amitriptyline, topiramate, valproate
  • CGRP antagonists - erenumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab, eptinezumab
 Verapamil

questions.text: A gardener presents with multiple vesicles on the hands and multiple eruptions along the lymphatic distribution. The lesions are limited to cutaneous tissues. On microscopy of tissue biopsy, flower-like clusters of conidia are seen. Which of the following statements is false about this disease?

choices.text: Medlar bodies are seen in this condition
It is caused by a dimorphic fungus
Itraconazole will be effective in this case
It is an example of subcutaneous mycoses

questions.solution:
The presence of multiple vesicles on the hands and multiple eruptions along lymphatics in a gardener and the microscopic finding of flower-like clusters of conidia are suggestive of sporotrichosis caused by Sporothrix schenckii.  In sporotrichosis, medlar bodies will not be seen. Medlar bodies or sclerotic bodies are seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis is a subcutaneous fungal infection caused by many species. In tissue, the lesions appear as spherical brown cells termed muriform or sclerotic bodies that divide by transverse septation.

S. schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that lives on vegetation such as grasses, trees, rose bushes, etc. It occurs in the yeast phase in tissues and in cultures at 37°C, and in the mycelia phase in nature and cultures at 25°C. The septate hyphae appear very thin and carry flower-like clusters of small conidia borne on delicate sterigmata. Asteroid bodies seen in sporotrichosis consist of a central basophilic yeast cell surrounded by radiating extensions of eosinophilic material.

Following traumatic inoculation into the skin as in thorn prick, S. schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous infection. The initial lesion appears following a trauma or thorn prick. The infection then spreads via the lymphatic channels to the lymph nodes. This results in secondary ulcers on the lymph nodes.

Treatment: 

  • Cutaneous form can be treated with oral or topical potassium iodide
  • Lymphocutaneous form – Itraconazole is effective in over 90% of patients with lymphocutaneous infection
  • For disseminated infection, amphotericin B is the drug of choice.

The image below shows the asteroid body seen in sporotrichosis:

Related Pearl: Common names of various fungal infections

Disease

Common name

Histoplasmosis

Darling’s disease

Sporotrichosis

Rose-thorn or Rose gardener’s disease

Para-coccidioidomycosis

South American blastomycosis

Coccidioidomycosis

Valley fever or desert rheumatism

Blastomycosis

North American blastomycosis, Gilchrist's disease

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient was suspected to have a seminoma of the testis. The mass was surgically removed and the specimen was sent for histopathological analysis. Which among the following findings is most likely to be seen microscopically?

choices.text: Derivatives of all three germ layers

questions.solution:
Microscopically, seminomas show a fried egg appearance of cells. This refers to cells with clear cytoplasm and a nucleus with a prominent nucleolus.

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor (around 50% of GCTs). It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP).

Patients usually present with painless testicular enlargement. Heaviness may be felt if the size is 2-3 times normal. Rarely, it may present with symptoms of metastatic disease.

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis.

The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance). The sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate. It is shown below.

Other options:

Option B: Schiller Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors, and appear as glomerulus-like structures with a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells in a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

Option C: Crystalloids of Reinke are seen in Leydig cell tumors. They are rod-shaped crystalloids seen in the cytoplasm of neoplastic Leydig cells.

Option D: Derivatives of all three germ layers- islands of bronchial epithelium, neural tissue, muscle, islands of cartilage, clusters of squamous epithelium, structures reminiscent of thyroid gland, bronchial or bronchiolar epithelium, and bits of the intestinal wall embedded in a fibrous or myxoid stroma may all be seen in a teratoma.

 

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

Related Pearl: Seminomatous germ-cell tumors (GCTs) vs Non-seminomatous GCT

Features Seminoma Non- seminomatous GCT
Age 2nd or 3rd decade (Never seen in prepubertal children) Occur at any age
Presentation Localized to the testis for a long time Aggressive tumors; present at an advanced clinical stage
Spread Lymphatic Hematogenous
Macroscopy Homogenous Variegated
Cell type Composed of primordial germ cells Composed of undifferentiated cells
Tumor marker Placental alkaline phosphatase AFP, HCG
Radio-therapy Radiosensitive Radioresistant
Prognosis Better Poor

AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein 

HCG: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

Related Pearl: Tumor Markers in Testicular Germ Cell Tumors

 

AFP

b-hCG

LDH

Seminoma

 -

+

++

Yolk sac tumor

+++

+

+

Choriocarcinoma

 -

+++

+

Embryonal carcinoma

+

+

++

Teratoma

 - 

 -

 -

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP: Raised in

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor

AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma (only in about 15% Seminomas)
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with kleptomania?
questions.solution:
Kleptomania is characterized by recurrent impulses to steal objects not needed for personal use or for monetary value. Here, the goal is not the object stolen but just the act of stealing. 

Kleptomania is characterized by the following:

  • Mounting tension before the act, followed by gratification and lessening of tension after the act.
  • The stealing is not planned and does not involve others. 
  • The stealing is not committed to express anger or vengeance and is not in response to a delusion or a hallucination.

It is more common in females.
